commit_message:
Enforce no_proxy when setting up ELK dashboards and rollups

There is no guarantee that all container IP addressess will be included
in an existing no_proxy environment variable. This will cause failures
when an http proxy is configured, but the proxy does not allow traffic
to 'hairpin' back to internal addresses.

This change forces no_proxy to the specific address of the kibana
and coordinator endpoints when the uri module is used to load dashboards
and configure rollups.

Change-Id: I669334c722cce79459b522e6e2d7e1aaec49ef24

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-02 10:38:57.000000000', 'message': 'Use nested virt in scenario jobs

virt_type option in nova-compute will be now set to "kvm" instead
of "qemu" if test job will be running on node which supports
nested virtualization.
In case of nodes where it's not supported, devstack will
automatically switch it to "qemu" again. It's in [1].

This should improve time of booting vms so tests should be finished
faster and there should be less errors with ssh to instance timeouts.

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-dev/devstack/tree/lib/nova#n289

Change-Id: Ifaa37398634f3cda73525363f8e197f03fd63a7d
'}]
commit_message:
Use nested virt in scenario jobs

virt_type option in nova-compute will be now set to "kvm" instead
of "qemu" if test job will be running on node which supports
nested virtualization.
In case of nodes where it's not supported, devstack will
automatically switch it to "qemu" again. It's in [1].

This should improve time of booting vms so tests should be finished
faster and there should be less errors with ssh to instance timeouts.

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-dev/devstack/tree/lib/nova#n289

Change-Id: Ifaa37398634f3cda73525363f8e197f03fd63a7d

commit_message:
Use nested virt in scenario jobs

virt_type option in nova-compute will be now set to "kvm" instead
of "qemu" if test job will be running on node which supports
nested virtualization.
In case of nodes where it's not supported, devstack will
automatically switch it to "qemu" again. It's in [1].

This should improve time of booting vms so tests should be finished
faster and there should be less errors with ssh to instance timeouts.

[1]
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-dev/devstack/tree/lib/nova#n289

Change-Id: Ia361f33f0b103ed44ef372c1464b3c0473a19291

(cherry picked from commit 85bb9f9a267dde15c19850af601216ec61315023)
"}, {'created': '2018-09-10 18:04:22.000000000', 'message': "Correct severe performance problem

When running our plugins we're seeing a severe performance impact in
the ansible run-time. As it turns out, within the linear strategy we're
looping over all physical hosts in an environment and pulling address
information out to store as a task variable. This action causes all
tasks to reload all {group,host}_vars for all hosts and that repetitive
action results in a massive slowdown, especially when there are many
hosts within the inventory.

Results from a normal OSA playbook run on 50 hosts:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    37m44.263s
  user    35m30.984s
  sys     2m23.252s

Results with the strategy plugin disabled on 50 hosts:
  time ANSIBLE_STRATEGY_PLUGINS=false openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    5m8.641s
  user    6m30.792s
  sys     1m32.512s

This change scopes the physical host look up to the task and target host
and adds conditionals around the process to ensure we're not forcing a lookup
that has no chance of succeeding.

Results with this patch applied on 50 hosts and no forks:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml
  real    6m40.573s
  user    7m53.336s
  sys     1m25.828s

Should anything like this come up again debug statements have been added
to the method so that we can enable verbose mode and know what is being
parsed.

Change-Id: I76af71ffe19b2a8afb18ed731f1362a4e399c613
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit 85bb9f9a267dde15c19850af601216ec61315023)
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Correct severe performance problem

When running our plugins we're seeing a severe performance impact in
the ansible run-time. As it turns out, within the linear strategy we're
looping over all physical hosts in an environment and pulling address
information out to store as a task variable. This action causes all
tasks to reload all {group,host}_vars for all hosts and that repetitive
action results in a massive slowdown, especially when there are many
hosts within the inventory.

Results from a normal OSA playbook run on 50 hosts:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    37m44.263s
  user    35m30.984s
  sys     2m23.252s

Results with the strategy plugin disabled on 50 hosts:
  time ANSIBLE_STRATEGY_PLUGINS=false openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    5m8.641s
  user    6m30.792s
  sys     1m32.512s

This change scopes the physical host look up to the task and target host
and adds conditionals around the process to ensure we're not forcing a lookup
that has no chance of succeeding.

Results with this patch applied on 50 hosts and no forks:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml
  real    6m40.573s
  user    7m53.336s
  sys     1m25.828s

Should anything like this come up again debug statements have been added
to the method so that we can enable verbose mode and know what is being
parsed.

Change-Id: I76af71ffe19b2a8afb18ed731f1362a4e399c613
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit 85bb9f9a267dde15c19850af601216ec61315023)
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Ensure logstash listens on ipv4 address

Upgrading the ELK stack to 6.4.0 leaves logstash only listening on
an ipv6 address and thereby unable to receive existing beats inputs.

This change makes the jvm prefer binding to ipv4 addresses.

Change-Id: I04a0fdbcb253a0a6a3bcc3759eb0b9d0f1962621

commit_message:
Add support to pullin distgit changes

This change addes the ability to bundle a packaging change during the
dlrn build with a code change. It can also be used to just test
packaging changes by switching the change repo to be the main repository
and include a distgit change only.

Change-Id: Ibeea3ef436dccaf36c254b232f922983cd101c5b

commit_message:
Use templates for cover and lower-constraints

Use openstack-tox-cover template, this runs the cover job as
non-voting in the check queue only.

Use openstack-lower-constraints-jobs template

Remove jobs that are part of the templates.

Change-Id: I58f3bc27aab2885514b8c6a8379e1c2214bd1afd

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-16 15:10:17.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Set/unset external MAC addresses for NAT entry when port is up/down

When using distributed floating IPs, we set the external MAC
address and logical port fields regardless whether the LSP
is up. For the particular use of Octavia LB VIP, which doesn't
ever get bound, the floating IP associated to it will never
get the flows installed by ovn-controller.

This patch changes the mechanism so that the DNAT entries get
updated only on port up/down changes. If the port remains
down, the external_mac will be cleared and traffic to those
FIPs will still go through the centralized router allowing.
When a port gets bound to a chassis, if DVR is enabled, the
mac_address field will be populated and traffic will go to
the compute node.

Change-Id: I0043984b4bb7b3780112aba170ffb956c48084d0
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Set/unset external MAC addresses for NAT entry when port is up/down

When using distributed floating IPs, we set the external MAC
address and logical port fields regardless whether the LSP
is up. For the particular use of Octavia LB VIP, which doesn't
ever get bound, the floating IP associated to it will never
get the flows installed by ovn-controller.

This patch changes the mechanism so that the DNAT entries get
updated only on port up/down changes. If the port remains
down, the external_mac will be cleared and traffic to those
FIPs will still go through the centralized router.
When a port gets bound to a chassis, if DVR is enabled, the
mac_address field will be populated and traffic will go to
the compute node.

Closes-bug: #1789686
Change-Id: I0043984b4bb7b3780112aba170ffb956c48084d0
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

Extract a devstack-minimal base job

For folks who are doing functional testing with less than the full set
of normal base services. Should be a no-op/ignorable for most people.

Change-Id: If14ee018c01995e0a5b6bcdaac9ddc8810c6d503
(cherry picked from commit 4d7e33757670890ec2c8a862d504c018df744f1c)

commit_message:
rabbit: do not mount /etc/rabbitmq in RO

Mounting /etc/rabbitmq in read-only is problematic when Puppet generates
the RabbitMQ cookie and fails to write in this directory.

Change-Id: I53e1fafd8b3567421458de5d25430d19c14446cb

commit_message:
fix prepare for numeric data

There is a case where there can be more than one build_name
with the same run_at[1] and without this change the request in [1]
will result in a KeyError[2]

The run_aggregator method is now updated to work with runs with
more than one build_name so that the expected_responses from
the unit tests make more sense and it makes it more ready to be
used for displaying run times in the grouped runs page.

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/726408/
[2] http://paste.openstack.org/show/726409/

Closes-Bug: #1785736

Change-Id: I66194d9fd753f2b094158103c37708148315629e

commit_message:
Fix overcloud plan tests

We recently rewrote the delete container functions in tripleo-common and
were incorrectly mocking out that functionality in tripleoclient. This
change updates the failing test to only check that we call the container
delete and not check functionality in the tripleo-common code.

Change-Id: Ia42d2100a98c004446eda4e48b6ba15e3396f14b
Closes-Bug: #1791120

commit_message:
Use swift bulk-delete when deleting a plan

Deleting swift containers (plans) with large numbers of files can
take longer than we'd like.

This patch uses the SwiftService API which contains an implementation
of bulk delete used by the swift CLI which speeds up delete operations.

Change-Id: I8362a7986e2e4ff0aecaf867faf47c24b658d15b
Closes-bug: #1615825

commit_message:
Reintroduce empty_container for tripleoclient

TripleoClient still uses empty_container. Put it back until we can
rework the tripleoclient code.

Change-Id: I96109c2452d7568da4a9374661a8ba8b9ba71458
Closes-Bug: #1791120

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks

    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-12 14:35:23.000000000', 'message': "Correct severe performance problem

When running our plugins we're seeing a severe performance impact in
the ansible run-time. As it turns out, within the linear strategy we're
looping over all physical hosts in an environment and pulling address
information out to store as a task variable. This action causes all
tasks to reload all {group,host}_vars for all hosts and that repetitive
action results in a massive slowdown, especially when there are many
hosts within the inventory.

Results from a normal OSA playbook run on 50 hosts:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    37m44.263s
  user    35m30.984s
  sys     2m23.252s

Results with the strategy plugin disabled on 50 hosts:
  time ANSIBLE_STRATEGY_PLUGINS=false openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    5m8.641s
  user    6m30.792s
  sys     1m32.512s

This change scopes the physical host look up to the task and target host
and adds conditionals around the process to ensure we're not forcing a lookup
that has no chance of succeeding.

Results with this patch applied on 50 hosts and no forks:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml
  real    6m40.573s
  user    7m53.336s
  sys     1m25.828s

Should anything like this come up again debug statements have been added
to the method so that we can enable verbose mode and know what is being
parsed.

Change-Id: Ic61364b304bd4cc614d3b945f06fc7297a65e440
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit 94c93e533f533206611ed70934b5819d7a318289)
"}, {'created': '2018-07-12 14:51:12.000000000', 'message': "Correct severe performance problem

action results in a massive slowdown, especially when there are many
hosts within the inventory.

Results from a normal OSA playbook run on 50 hosts:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    37m44.263s
  user    35m30.984s
  sys     2m23.252s

Results with the strategy plugin disabled on 50 hosts:
  time ANSIBLE_STRATEGY_PLUGINS=false openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    5m8.641s
  user    6m30.792s
  sys     1m32.512s

This change scopes the physical host look up to the task and target host
and adds conditionals around the process to ensure we're not forcing a lookup
that has no chance of succeeding.

Results with this patch applied on 50 hosts and no forks:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml
  real    6m40.573s
  user    7m53.336s
  sys     1m25.828s

Should anything like this come up again debug statements have been added
to the method so that we can enable verbose mode and know what is being
parsed.

Change-Id: I76af71ffe19b2a8afb18ed731f1362a4e399c613
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit 94c93e533f533206611ed70934b5819d7a318289)
"}]
commit_message:
Correct severe performance problem

When running our plugins we're seeing a severe performance impact in
the ansible run-time. As it turns out, within the linear strategy we're
looping over all physical hosts in an environment and pulling address
information out to store as a task variable. This action causes all
tasks to reload all {group,host}_vars for all hosts and that repetitive
action results in a massive slowdown, especially when there are many
hosts within the inventory.

Results from a normal OSA playbook run on 50 hosts:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    37m44.263s
  user    35m30.984s
  sys     2m23.252s

Results with the strategy plugin disabled on 50 hosts:
  time ANSIBLE_STRATEGY_PLUGINS=false openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    5m8.641s
  user    6m30.792s
  sys     1m32.512s

This change scopes the physical host look up to the task and target host
and adds conditionals around the process to ensure we're not forcing a lookup
that has no chance of succeeding.

Results with this patch applied on 50 hosts and no forks:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml
  real    6m40.573s
  user    7m53.336s
  sys     1m25.828s

Should anything like this come up again debug statements have been added
to the method so that we can enable verbose mode and know what is being
parsed.

Change-Id: I76af71ffe19b2a8afb18ed731f1362a4e399c613
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit 94c93e533f533206611ed70934b5819d7a318289)

commit_message:
Correct severe performance problem

When running our plugins we're seeing a severe performance impact in
the ansible run-time. As it turns out, within the linear strategy we're
looping over all physical hosts in an environment and pulling address
information out to store as a task variable. This action causes all
tasks to reload all {group,host}_vars for all hosts and that repetitive
action results in a massive slowdown, especially when there are many
hosts within the inventory.

Results from a normal OSA playbook run on 50 hosts:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    37m44.263s
  user    35m30.984s
  sys     2m23.252s

Results with the strategy plugin disabled on 50 hosts:
  time ANSIBLE_STRATEGY_PLUGINS=false openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    5m8.641s
  user    6m30.792s
  sys     1m32.512s

This change scopes the physical host look up to the task and target host
and adds conditionals around the process to ensure we're not forcing a lookup
that has no chance of succeeding.

Results with this patch applied on 50 hosts and no forks:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml
  real    6m40.573s
  user    7m53.336s
  sys     1m25.828s

Should anything like this come up again debug statements have been added
to the method so that we can enable verbose mode and know what is being
parsed.

Change-Id: I76af71ffe19b2a8afb18ed731f1362a4e399c613
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Document differences and similaries between extra specs and hints

Scheduler hints are not really documented very well at all except
for being mentioned per scheduler filter in the admin configuration
guide, nor are they documented within relation to flavor extra
specs which are both used for impacting scheduling decisions and
are choices that a deployer has to make based on how they configure
their cloud.

This change adds a document about scheduler hints and how they are
similar to and different from flavor extra specs, including end
user discoverability and interoperability, and thoughts on which
should be used if writing a custom scheduler filter.

The TODO in the API guide is also resolved by linking to this
document.

Change-Id: Ib1f35baacf59efafb9e4bccfcc4f0025d99ad5b2

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-15 15:25:57.000000000', 'message': "Fix cancel_all_events event name parsing

The cancel_all_events function was incorrectly assuming
that event tags didn't have dashes in them, but they all
do since they are either port or volume IDs, which are UUIDs.

Instead of just storing our event data indexed by the composite
event key, we should just store the name and tag distinctly so
that there is no question about how to dissect the two from the
key later. This is all internal record-keeping inside of the
compute manager, so we can change it to whatever we want.

This includes a slight change to the internal virtapi interface
for wait_for_instance_event(), which removes the ability to
pass composite event keys as strings instead of (name, tag)
tuples. In reality, none of the virt code was using the key string
format, so this just cleans up a few tests that were. It makes
that interface less ambiguous, which is good anyway.

Change-Id: I15f041e820c2dabe82e8e25bf77f9cc86330a76a
Closes-Bug: #1760303
(cherry picked from commit d9369d034cb0694def2510885ddfb9b039cbad49)

commit_message:
Fix cancel_all_events event name parsing

The cancel_all_events function was incorrectly assuming
that event tags didn't have dashes in them, but they all
do since they are either port or volume IDs, which are UUIDs.

Instead of just storing our event data indexed by the composite
event key, we should just store the name and tag distinctly so
that there is no question about how to dissect the two from the
key later. This is all internal record-keeping inside of the
compute manager, so we can change it to whatever we want.

This includes a slight change to the internal virtapi interface
for wait_for_instance_event(), which removes the ability to
pass composite event keys as strings instead of (name, tag)
tuples. In reality, none of the virt code was using the key string
format, so this just cleans up a few tests that were. It makes
that interface less ambiguous, which is good anyway.

Change-Id: I15f041e820c2dabe82e8e25bf77f9cc86330a76a
Closes-Bug: #1760303
(cherry picked from commit d9369d034cb0694def2510885ddfb9b039cbad49)

[{'created': '2018-09-05 21:40:14.000000000', 'message': "Remove redundant image GET call in _do_rebuild_instance

During a rebuild on the compute, the rebuild_instance method
fetches the new image from glance once to get the image_meta
for the RT.rebuild_claim, and then _do_rebuild_instance gets
the new image again to get image_meta for the driver.spawn/rebuild
method. Since it's the same image_meta either way, we can just
pass the image_meta from rebuild_instance to _do_rebuild_instance
and avoid the redundant GET call to glance.

Change-Id: I037a83f0a8cb4cdf87514dd4133da8bfedb564f5
Closes-Bug: #1790972
"}]
commit_message:
Remove redundant image GET call in _do_rebuild_instance

During a rebuild on the compute, the rebuild_instance method
fetches the new image from glance once to get the image_meta
for the RT.rebuild_claim, and then _do_rebuild_instance gets
the new image again to get image_meta for the driver.spawn/rebuild
method. Since it's the same image_meta either way, we can just
pass the image_meta from rebuild_instance to _do_rebuild_instance
and avoid the redundant GET call to glance.

Change-Id: I037a83f0a8cb4cdf87514dd4133da8bfedb564f5
Closes-Bug: #1790972

(1 comment)

Interesting. I rather thought this was the plan all along, so seeing debate about it is confusing to me. Which is not to say that I like it. I would actualy prefer the "ask placement for more info" alternative (doing a GET to /resource_providers) all over the place and there be no provider summaries at all.

But that ship has sailed and we decided that we should have a useful provider_summaries. Since we have decided that, that means we need to represent  enough information for the providers to be constituted on the client side, including resources and hierarchy.

Effectively this spec is describing a bug fix for existing use cases, not something to satisfy a new use case.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-04-11 17:55:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> Effectively this spec is describing a bug fix for existing use cases, not something to satisfy a new use case.

What existing use cases, using only in-tree code, are broken without this?'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-04-11 18:03:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

The latest patch set is much more clear in the problem description, thank you for that. I was about to -2 this otherwise for continuing to overwrite my -1, but this makes some more sense now. I'm not totally sold yet since I've just diffed the versions, so I need to come back to this later."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-04-11 18:04:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> > Effectively this spec is describing a bug fix for existing use
 > cases, not something to satisfy a new use case.
 > 
 > What existing use cases, using only in-tree code, are broken
 > without this?

Is the question about whether there is an urgent need for this versus a "we'd like to lay the right ground work"?'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-04-11 18:07:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> Is the question about whether there is an urgent need for this versus a "we'd like to lay the right ground work"?

Yes, that's the crux of my issue. Until we have something concrete that we know is going to leverage this, I'd prefer to hold off on making the change before exploring alternatives, or if this will even be all we need for whatever said things are that need this.

Like, does this allow us to rewrite/improve the existing NUMATopologyFilter and if so, how?

Would we have a flavor with granular resource requests that are just NUMA resources? If so, then the problem description makes sense in that we're querying placement for resources that are found in the subtree but we need to get the root provider uuid back so we can query compute nodes from the nova cell DB as that's the thing that is used to create the HostState objects used by the scheudler and it's filters/weighers.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-04-11 19:57:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(3 comments)

Thanks Tetsuro for providing the much needed detail for people like me who don't have so much knowledge of placement provider trees. With this detail, I can see the problem and how the proposal addresses it.

If I understand correctly, there is already a problem at-present when using the NUMATopologyFilter in the case where the user requests only NUMA (child) resources as part of the instance flavor. If that's true, then I'm on board with doing this proposal."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-16 22:21:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

This spec doesn't address the question of whether the provider summaries include resource *classes* not involved in the request.  But it's worth pointing out that your code [1] does just that.  I'm happy with this spec as it stands, but it'll mean your code will have to change accordingly.

OR you can amend this spec to include that piece.

OR you can put it in a separate spec and we can argue about it separately.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/558045/"}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-04-17 02:52:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-17 20:35:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

What I said last time still kind of applies. Even though I was wrong about it not being in the spec (sorry about that) the lack of "uninvolved" resource classes in the provider_summaries doesn't feature in your problem description.  It needs to.  Or you can take that part out of Work Items and we can discuss it in a separate bp/spec.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-04-18 08:20:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-04-18 08:40:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

@Matt Riedemann

> Would we have a flavor with granular resource requests that are just NUMA resources?

Yes, especially in cases where the operator wants to manage NUMA resources in placement.
We are going to make it optional though in @bauzas’s`NUMA Topology with Resource Providers` spec[1]. 
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/552924/

NFV operators are currently in Queens forced to see compute nodes’ DB to get the status of NUMA resources.
But this enables us to get CPU/Memory usage for each NUMA nodes via placement. 

@melanie witt

> With this detail, I can see the problem and how the proposal addresses it.

Thanks to your advice. Thank you so much.

@Eric Fried

> but the text above doesn't really explain/justify why we need to do this part.

Than you so much for the quick response. (As always!!)
I added one more case to describe it. Please see if it makes sense."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-18 12:38:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1

But that's mostly noise at this stage.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-04-25 14:51:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Return resources of entire trees in Placement

This spec aims to extend the placement ``GET /allocation_candidates``
API to include all resource class inventories of entire tree in
``provider_summaries`` field in the response body.

Change-Id: I7992e16dd63cc2c5d22c3c3ce58adae9ad741569
Blueprint: placement-return-all-resources

commit_message:
Add release note for parameter removal

In [1] the cinder::api::nova_catalog_admin_info parameter was removed,
having been deprecated in the Rocky cycle. That patch's release note
failed to mention the parameter was removed. This patch adds the missing
release note.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/600164

Change-Id: I55dac753289a3125a5902599a51bf9ac385c7628

subject: Ignore conditions when reparsing ResourceDefinition
messages: [{'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2018-09-03 04:38:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-09-04 14:20:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nLow risk change. Fixes a bug in the legacy path.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-09-10 16:34:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-03 04:38:45.000000000', 'message': "Ignore conditions when reparsing ResourceDefinition

In the legacy path we reparse a resource definition to refer to a different
StackDefinition when copying a resource definition into the existing
template (as the resource is updated) or into the backup stack's template.
However, the resources 'condition' may reference conditionals that are not
defined in the template it is being copied into (e.g. during a stack update
that creates a new condition), and in this case the destination template
will become unusable.

Since the fact that we care about the resource definition at all indicates
that the condition was enabled, just ignore the condition after reparsing.
This is consistent with what we do for 'if' macros, which is to resolve the
condition part during reparsing.

Change-Id: I59a374435f6275badc8124efbd7b7db2e36e2de5
Story: #2003558
Task: 24847
(cherry picked from commit 92101b18e260665718fb9d795c3f6ee2148f8ac5)
"}]
commit_message:
Ignore conditions when reparsing ResourceDefinition

In the legacy path we reparse a resource definition to refer to a different
StackDefinition when copying a resource definition into the existing
template (as the resource is updated) or into the backup stack's template.
However, the resources 'condition' may reference conditionals that are not
defined in the template it is being copied into (e.g. during a stack update
that creates a new condition), and in this case the destination template
will become unusable.

Since the fact that we care about the resource definition at all indicates
that the condition was enabled, just ignore the condition after reparsing.
This is consistent with what we do for 'if' macros, which is to resolve the
condition part during reparsing.

Change-Id: I59a374435f6275badc8124efbd7b7db2e36e2de5
Story: #2003558
Task: 24847
(cherry picked from commit 92101b18e260665718fb9d795c3f6ee2148f8ac5)

Change ID isn't right but the right commit is referenced so we should be ok."}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2018-08-27 12:46:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Lucio, thank you for these backports! As Jay noted, the commit message hints at a procedural issue.

The "cherry picked from commit" is supposed to specify a git hash, and not the Change-Id associated with the commit. The easiest way to achieve this is to use "git cherry-pick -x" (the "-x" option).

The point is the patches for each branch should all have the same Change-Id. You do not want to generate a fresh Change-Id for each backport.

See [1] for an example of another patch that has been backported to stable/queens and stable/pike. Note how they all have the same Change-Id, and the backports reference git hashes. The stable/queens patch references the master patch, and the stable/pike patch references the stable/queens patch. The "cherry picked from commit" lines accumulate with each additional backport.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/q/I1438d0bd4a43e1813dfb0a6e9b3c4a177c2fee8f'}, {'account_id': 18058, 'date': '2018-09-10 19:19:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the detailed instructions Alan, I'll do it right next time :-)"}]

[{'created': '2018-08-17 00:23:48.000000000', 'message': "NetApp ONTAP: Fix driver force detach operations

Cinder API supports os-force_detach, which once invoked can call the
driver finalize_connection passing a 'None' connector. When receiving
this, the driver should handle this call by terminating every
connection between the specified volume and any host it is mapped to.

This patch fixes this behavior for NetApp ONTAP iSCSI and FC drivers.

Closes-bug: #1783582
(cherry picked from commit I2a55961b62297f0fa4e678929f69cafc5aa17bd9)

Change-Id: Id3ad0fb4ea46d09033435641f39af04cbffea77f
"}]
commit_message:
NetApp ONTAP: Fix driver force detach operations

Cinder API supports os-force_detach, which once invoked can call the
driver finalize_connection passing a 'None' connector. When receiving
this, the driver should handle this call by terminating every
connection between the specified volume and any host it is mapped to.

This patch fixes this behavior for NetApp ONTAP iSCSI and FC drivers.

Closes-bug: #1783582
(cherry picked from commit I2a55961b62297f0fa4e678929f69cafc5aa17bd9)

Change-Id: Id3ad0fb4ea46d09033435641f39af04cbffea77f

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: I5239feb9ade5ff7530fd50e0f1125283a7acd9e4
Story: #2002586
Task: #24288

commit_message:
Insert break lines when showing FFWD upgrade operator warning.

This is a simple patch to display properly the
warning text for operators when running the FFWD.
Also, rephrases the warning message as FFWD are
now fully tested.

Resolves: rhbz#1566294
Closes-Bug: 1785829
Change-Id: I0174a075e82d41ee9eacb4bdf0b4ba70cfae1007
(cherry picked from commit a21df11158e44e87a468477981871bab8c2b55dd)

commit_message:
NetApp SolidFire: Fix CG snapshot deletion

This adds a function missing on the driver that was making impossible
to delete a consistency group snapshot.

Change-Id: I4d6a4f5cf4f4f0f751e1378d3747d2aacc050d24
Closes-bug: #1788418
Closes-bug: #1777862

Some users may not want *_image_location operations to be
restricted to role:admin so this patch allows that to be
configurable and sets the default to be False since
enabling this by default is breaking RBD COW clones in
Nova for non-admin users (and anywhere else that relies
on that information).

Change-Id: I8c293d6036bc1d6104dab5458f6915968459a09e

(cherry picked from commit 9e2af26b6d10c145dcb51dfb9e54bd8b2906bcfa)

commit_message:
Make image location ops policy configurable

Some users may not want *_image_location operations to be
restricted to role:admin so this patch allows that to be
configurable and sets the default to be False since
enabling this by default is breaking RBD COW clones in
Nova for non-admin users (and anywhere else that relies
on that information).

Change-Id: I8c293d6036bc1d6104dab5458f6915968459a09e
Closes-Bug: #1786144
(cherry picked from commit 9e2af26b6d10c145dcb51dfb9e54bd8b2906bcfa)

subject: import zuul job settings from project-config
messages:
[{'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-09-09 03:07:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-09-09 18:18:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Doug, can you tell me how to review this? I haven't really followed the changes that zuul v3 has brought with respect to job definitions so I'm not sure how to evaluate this. The .zuul.yaml looks like it just references jobs defined elsewhere (and defines the irrelevant files, which I understand).

Two jobs failed here, but seemingly for reasons unrelated to this change, so do I just need to sanity check the irrelevant files or is there more change this triggers elsewhere?"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-09-10 10:22:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

lgtm as per jobs definition removal proposal in this - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/601032/2/zuul.d/projects.yaml

Extra this patch does is to remove excluding the stable/newton /mitaka branches which is ok to remove now. 

@Dan, you can check this patch where imported job definitions are being proposed to  remove from project-config side - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/601032/2/zuul.d/projects.yaml'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-09-10 11:44:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Doug, can you tell me how to review this? I haven't really followed
 > the changes that zuul v3 has brought with respect to job
 > definitions so I'm not sure how to evaluate this. The .zuul.yaml
 > looks like it just references jobs defined elsewhere (and defines
 > the irrelevant files, which I understand).
 > 
 > Two jobs failed here, but seemingly for reasons unrelated to this
 > change, so do I just need to sanity check the irrelevant files or
 > is there more change this triggers elsewhere?

These patches should be no-ops. They are just copying the settings from one place to another, so zuul shouldn't be doing anything different as they land. As Ghanshyam points out, you could compare the settings in the patch to the settings for the same repo in the project-config repo, either by looking at the patch to remove those settings or by looking at the current version of zuul.d/projects.yaml."}, {'account_id': 28543, 'date': '2018-09-10 13:17:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-09-10 14:36:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Fix to enable `--config-file` option

This commit sets the `--config-file` path to the environment variables
`TEMPEST_CONFIG_DIR` and `TEMPEST_CONFIG` to enable the option as a
workaround.
The `path` is passed to `set_config_path()` however, the running test
process is a child process which is a different instance.

Change-Id: I8a65ee0f82e41f9659b3f40e2685c0ee0f290342
Related-Bug: #1783751

commit_message:
py3: add support for switching workloads from py2->py3

For migration of services to execution under Python 3 add support
for a Charm class to declare a set of packages to purge on upgrade.

This allows the target release Charm class to remove Python 2
modules installed as part of prior charm versions.

After the purge call, autoremove will also be called to purge any
other packages that where indirectly installed.

Add new python_version attribute for charm classes, supporting
conditional install of python{3}-memcache for token caching.

Change-Id: I17a93524fb7ec134b4a3a61cd0e86977daf49c4e

commit_message:
Resolve E004 File did not end with a newline

I have no idea why this is only showing up after a merge,
but it is doing so on stable/rocky patches in the linters
(bashate) test. This patch should resolve it.

Change-Id: Ib5e34b16c4bacc459883d2be8d503d9f1b22ea0d

I don't read this as a hard deadline, just as the current expectation of the people involved in the extraction.  If that changes, nothing will be required to change this commit message, the next patch will just be delayed longer."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-08-31 10:47:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For clarity: The reason I put an indication of timing in the commit messages is because a a few different people involved with the placement extraction, throughout the several email threads and IRC conversations, asked that if we were not going to be immediately changing governance then we need to make sure that there is documentary evidence somewhere that there is a commitment to make the change before the end of the Stein cycle. This so the situation has a concrete milestone to strive for. Something that can be pointed at when or if more reasons to "wait and see" were raised. These comments were from people who are strung out from the ambiguity, the waiting, and the repeated debates.

The timeline was further narrowed to "Stein-2" based on conversation that happened in IRC [1] which suggested that some gap time before the end of the cycle was appropriate to leave room for PTL elections, PTG arrangement and whatever other process is around.

Since we've abandoned "now" as an option, I personally don't care when the governance change over happens except that it be relatively soon (before T) and that a shared goal is documented (for the "point to it" reasons described above). As I've said before, different governance should mean very little technical difference for the people actively working on placement (it will start from the same people). It is the symbolic difference of something being accomplished and shifted that is important for OpenStack at large.

I started the first commit [2] on placement in June of 2016. That commit message opens with:

    The placement API will initially host resource provider
    information and then will grow to provide a full placement
    service. Eventually it will be fully extracted from Nova.

Prior to that commit I had been doing the initial exploratory work outside of nova completely, but people wanted it brought in.

At each mid-cycle, PTG or Forum since then I've tried to move the extraction process forward. Because we used the term "Eventually" when talking about when extraction would happen it was easy to put it off because of other priorities, lack of review bandwidth or a belief that there is some kind of strong coupling between placement and nova that needed to be resolved.

We've finally reached the point where we have an extracted repo [3] (doesn't work yet, of course, but we have had several successful experiments at making it work). This is fantastic and cause for celebration but it is not complete.

That commit message above says "fully". Until Placement is its own project, we're not done. I fear people have got the wrong impression about why I'm driving this so hard. It's simply that more than two years ago we, as a group, decided we'd do a thing and I've been trying to make it happen, all the way.


[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/%23openstack-tc.2018-08-23.log.html#t2018-08-23T15:43:12
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/329149/
[3] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/placement'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-08-31 11:14:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I started the first commit [2] on placement in June of 2016. That

 > The placement API will initially host resource provider

Since I know someone might get hung up on this, the above was the first commit of placement as an HTTP service and the existence of the nova/api/openstack/placement package. There was earlier work to establish the persistence layer and object model starting as early as January 2016, on this topic:

https://review.openstack.org/#/q/topic:bp/resource-providers'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-08-31 11:24:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-08-31 11:25:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

the repo is already created AFAIK...'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-08-31 16:06:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

I have personally expressed many times that the technical and governance transition should be two different things. 

I believe the two step process is the ideal thing for déployers and deployment tools. Given that there seems to be issues in nature of working together, i would like to propose that the placement and Nova team sit down to discuss and get through these issues. 

I am +1 for making placememt a deliverable, I’m not +1 to tying that with the governance change. Let’s sit down and discuss this.  I wouldn’t mind having to run this thing where we sit down at the PTG to iron this out in person, to which then we can draft up a proposal.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-08-31 17:00:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is, as seems common these days, getting out of hand.

I put up "stein-2" because it seemed a reasonable way to not have a chaotic mess at the end of the cycle. If that's no good I can either completely remove the paragraph so no mention of governance is made or change it to whatever someone else thinks it should be.

The technical change has already happened, we're in progress and I'm optimistic that we can do it. It's nice to see the concerted effort that is happening already in the repo to move forward.

I, honestly, can not discern the reasons why the change in governance is meaningful to the people who do not want it. To me it is meaningful because it allows me to say "look we did it, yay!". I get the impression it has similar meaning to other people as well.

On the day governance changes, whether that is today or a year from today, what changes for the people who want to exercise more flexibility over when it happens? What about that makes it more risky for nova when the people involved are still all the same people doing all the same things? Please be open and honest about this. 

Also, somebody please tell me how to change this patch so that we can merge the placement repo into nova's deliverables and get that step done.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-08-31 17:38:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Also, somebody please tell me how to change this patch so that we
 > can merge the placement repo into nova's deliverables and get that
 > step done.

Remove the language about an expectation that by the Stein-2 milestone placement will become its own official project.

Seems straightforward to me.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-31 19:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-31 19:32:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-08-31 20:19:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> This is, as seems common these days, getting out of hand.
 > 
 > I put up "stein-2" because it seemed a reasonable way to not have a
 > chaotic mess at the end of the cycle. If that's no good I can
 > either completely remove the paragraph so no mention of governance
 > is made or change it to whatever someone else thinks it should be.
 > 
 > The technical change has already happened, we're in progress and
 > I'm optimistic that we can do it. It's nice to see the concerted
 > effort that is happening already in the repo to move forward.
 
I don't think we can call the technical change "done" until we have all of the right tempest jobs setup on the repo and the grenade job deploying a new placement package on the stein side and rolling through an upgrade smoothly. The technical change has started, I'm glad it's making progress, let's keep it up and get to the "done" point for the technical extraction piece.

 > I, honestly, can not discern the reasons why the change in
 > governance is meaningful to the people who do not want it. To me it
 > is meaningful because it allows me to say "look we did it, yay!". I
 > get the impression it has similar meaning to other people as well.
 
Hopefully this was made clear from our discussion in the -tc channel today [1], but to add it here as well, it is meaningful to me because it means a separation of priorities -- placement becoming an independent entity with its own priorities that are free not to be nova's. And I do want to see that future. I think that doing it now or selecting an arbitrary switch date is not helpful, and adds more complication to something that is already hard. I want us to get some work done before we create the potential for separate, non-aligning priorities. I hope we can discuss this together and come up with a set of work items we all agree to complete before we switch the governance and begin the potential divergence. Some have said, "why would priorities of the two projects diverge?" And I say, that's the point of splitting governance. If there was no want to be able to diverge, no one would be wanting to split governance. I think we should start to diverge after some minimal set of work items we all agree on, being that we're right in the middle of major work like integrating nested resource providers and leveraging reshaper for vGPUs. Operators and users are depending on us to deliver this work that we're in the middle of. I think we should make an effort to flush some of that work out of the queue before we split.

 > On the day governance changes, whether that is today or a year from
 > today, what changes for the people who want to exercise more
 > flexibility over when it happens? What about that makes it more
 > risky for nova when the people involved are still all the same
 > people doing all the same things? Please be open and honest about
 > this.
 
I hope that the conversation today in the -tc channel made it clear why I don't want to split governance today or at an arbitrary date. If it is not clear, let me know.

 > Also, somebody please tell me how to change this patch so that we
 > can merge the placement repo into nova's deliverables and get that
 > step done.

I think removing the line about the expected switchover date would be the simplest way to get this patch into a shape that everyone agrees on.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/%23openstack-tc.2018-08-31.log.html#t2018-08-31T17:08:36'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-09-01 10:48:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

> > The technical change has already happened, we're in progress and
 > > I'm optimistic that we can do it. It's nice to see the concerted
 > > effort that is happening already in the repo to move forward.
 > 
 > I don't think we can call the technical change "done" until we have

Sorry, when I said "technical change" I simply meant the creation and seeding of the repo, not the creation of a working placement. I agree, we have a long and complex way to go on that, but we've crossed a major hurdle and we have a plan.

 > Hopefully this was made clear from our discussion in the -tc
 > channel today [1],

Yes, that conversation helped some, thank you.

 > but to add it here as well, it is meaningful to
 > me because it means a separation of priorities -- placement
 > becoming an independent entity with its own priorities that are
 > free not to be nova's.

Where I guess we disagree is whether "priorities...free not to be nova's" is a good or bad thing and also the risks if that freedom is exercised. I feel that freedom is a good thing (both in a fundamental sense of what is "good" but also in terms of what is good for OpenStack) and the risk is low because "nova people" and "placement people" are the same people.

Speaking for myself only, I have no specific feature or functionality priorities with placement that are not also nova priorities. There may be nova priorities that I'm not aware of, however.

But we're going round in circles on these points, so I guess until there's some shift in what is going to be said, we may as well stop beating it.

 > I think removing the line about the expected switchover date would
 > be the simplest way to get this patch into a shape that everyone
 > agrees on.

I'll do that because moving this forward is good, but I hope we have sufficient evidence (here and elsewhere) that apparently there's a lot more to talk about before there's true alignment between all the people involved and that much of that mis-alignment is related to many more people than Chris and Mel.

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-09-01 10:51:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-09-01 15:57:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-01 21:21:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-09-01 21:25:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2018-09-02 02:46:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-09-03 11:41:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-09-04 12:58:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-30 22:26:01.000000000', 'message': 'Add placement deliverable to nova

Add openstack/placement as repo under the nova project to provide an
interim home for placement as it is extracted from nova to its own code
repository. The new repo is created by the change at the depends-on
below, which will seed the repo from a filtered clone of nova. The new
repo will initially have as its core reviewers existing nova-cores plus
a small number of additional cores selected from placement contributors.

The expectation is that by the Stein 2 milestone, placement will become
its own official project, to help make it clear that placement is a
service for all of openstack, and to help narrow (slightly) the scope of
nova. Near that milestone another change will be posted proposing the
change in governance.

Change-Id: I227f7d109de798fea65569e8a93de8b233be591b
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/598362
'}, {'created': '2018-09-01 10:51:02.000000000', 'message': 'Add placement deliverable to nova

Add openstack/placement as repo under the nova project to indicate the

commit_message:
Add placement deliverable to nova

Add openstack/placement as repo under the nova project to indicate the
the home for placement as it is extracted from the nova code repository
to its own.

The new repo [1] was created by the (merged) change at the depends-on
below, which seeded the repo from a filtered clone of nova. See that
change for more details on the disposition of the repo and the immediate
plans.

[1] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/placement

Change-Id: I227f7d109de798fea65569e8a93de8b233be591b
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/598362

commit_message:
Update repo information for API-SIG

The api-wg became the api-sig so this change moves the repo reference
from technical-committee-repos to sigs-repos. In the process the name
of the repo (which changed a few weeks ago) is updated.

Change-Id: Id947ad72b1ffeb9d1b0065dd1964be19fa557a81

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-29 12:32:55.000000000', 'message': 'import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: Ie0746e2245c265ce1eb131f157a37d55a20ce085

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: Ie0746e2245c265ce1eb131f157a37d55a20ce085
Story: #2002586
Task: #24294

commit_message:
Move bootstrap-ansible and passwords to run_osa tag

Allows for deployment/bootstrap of OSA to be skipped
by skipping run_osa while still allowing configuration
to be added during pre_config_osa.

Change-Id: I40b0c8209f03c7e9543c7c688f2ef8ba2ebdf72d

commit_message:
Clean up role tests

Now that we're using the general templates, we can slim down
the role test definitions. We can also remove tests which are
not being watched, or which are fundamentally broken. With
this we can also remove unused scripts/plays.

We do the following:

1. We remove the 'ssl' job, given that the person working on
   that is no longer doing so, and no-one else has picked up
   the work.

Change-Id: Iaf3d6226e72ba542f06b9805c4e017904f786029

commit_message:
Remove container_registry param from package update action

The package_update_plan mistrl workflow is invoked in upgrade|update|
ceph-upgrade|ffwd-upgrade prepare clis. The container registry
parameter is being removed and we will use treat it as a regular
environment file (see depends-on). This removes it from the Mistral
action and keeps it defaulted in the workflow to prevent
chicken-and-egg issues with CI. We'll remove the workflow parameter in
a follow-up patch.

Partial-Bug: #1785825
Co-Authored-By: Jiri Stransky <jistr@jistr.com>
Related: https://review.openstack.org/570893 python-tripleoclient
Change-Id: I4130dd1eea6caec82dcb4a699875f2951693148f
(cherry picked from commit c837491161c24ca7bb9fbfcbb3b51d88c8d7b9d1)

subject: Run online data migrations
messages: [{'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2018-09-10 08:17:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2018-09-10 10:55:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked\n\nThis patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/queens as commit dded2d427c10021a4804f38d371413e171b1cf31'}, {'account_id': 20775, 'date': '2018-09-10 10:56:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 22865, 'date': '2018-09-10 11:36:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-10 08:17:08.000000000', 'message': "Run online data migrations

We always run DB sync in deploy_tasks, ensuring that the database is
up to date. We should follow up with online data migrations
too.

Doing this via docker_config has 2 purposes:

* We can easily ensure this happens in a container with the right
  config files mounted.

* We can even apply this via a minor update. This is important because
  we'll have to backport this all the way to Pike and apply it there
  using Pike containers, before upgrading to Queens containers.

There's an additional issue to consider: In Puppet service variant we
ran the online migrations for release X before upgrading to X+1, but
the proposed Docker variant migrations for X run with upgrade to
X. This means that when switching from non-containerized to
containerized, we'll need to run migrations twice, to correctly switch
between the aforementioned approaches.

Change-Id: I2eb6c7c42d7e7aea4a78a892790e42bc5371f792
Closes-Bug: #1790474
(cherry picked from commit 16405ff92842b4a3583edae00590c3fc760a05c9)
"}]
commit_message:
Run online data migrations

We always run DB sync in deploy_tasks, ensuring that the database is
up to date. We should follow up with online data migrations
too.

Doing this via docker_config has 2 purposes:

* We can easily ensure this happens in a container with the right
  config files mounted.

* We can even apply this via a minor update. This is important because
  we'll have to backport this all the way to Pike and apply it there
  using Pike containers, before upgrading to Queens containers.

There's an additional issue to consider: In Puppet service variant we
ran the online migrations for release X before upgrading to X+1, but
the proposed Docker variant migrations for X run with upgrade to
X. This means that when switching from non-containerized to
containerized, we'll need to run migrations twice, to correctly switch
between the aforementioned approaches.

Change-Id: I2eb6c7c42d7e7aea4a78a892790e42bc5371f792
Closes-Bug: #1790474
(cherry picked from commit 16405ff92842b4a3583edae00590c3fc760a05c9)

commit_message:
Clean up role tests

Now that we're using the general templates, we can slim down
the role test definitions. We can also remove tests which are
not being watched, or which are fundamentally broken. With
this we can also remove unused scripts/plays.

We do the following:

1. We remove the opensuse-150 tests, as they are not passing,
   nor have they since their inception.

Change-Id: I37a9f2af33d47a8edd5788d1504bb2c956356235

commit_message:
Improve error messages of validators

The current error message from validation step doesn't include what
plugin fails and by which validator. This information is available only
in debug mode.

Without this information it is hard to understand what is going wrong.

Change-Id: I4e0bc3eb36c3d8116a2e867b48604b4cc514580a

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-06 08:52:19.000000000', 'message': 'Fix gateway's router port marked as DOWN

This patch is fixing a problem which left the external/gateway's router
port with status DOWN even after the port was bound to a chassis.

Since the Logical_Router_Port table in OVNNB does not have a "up" column
(like the Logical_Switch_Port table has) the status of those ports can
not be updpated based on it. Therefore, this patch uses the "chassis"
column for that. If the router port has the "chassis" column in OVNNB
database set, the binding and status ACTIVE will be set in Neutron
otherwise it status will be udpated to DOWN (if it's not DOWN yet).

Closes-Bug: #1715126
Change-Id: I91026204eae6df18be47df02f99db2f95c428e2b
(cherry picked from commit 3d575d19b850134044bba8b89cdb9953c17a5ca7)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix gateway's router port marked as DOWN

This patch is fixing a problem which left the external/gateway's router
port with status DOWN even after the port was bound to a chassis.

Since the Logical_Router_Port table in OVNNB does not have a "up" column
(like the Logical_Switch_Port table has) the status of those ports can
not be updpated based on it. Therefore, this patch uses the "chassis"
column for that. If the router port has the "chassis" column in OVNNB
database set, the binding and status ACTIVE will be set in Neutron
otherwise it status will be udpated to DOWN (if it's not DOWN yet).

Closes-Bug: #1715126
Change-Id: I91026204eae6df18be47df02f99db2f95c428e2b
(cherry picked from commit 3d575d19b850134044bba8b89cdb9953c17a5ca7)

URL decode swift-get-node command line arguments.
It allow operator to locate an account/container/object with a space in his name.
Space should be replace by a %20 in command line argument.

Closes-Bug: #1791302

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: I4f4a3072d6e76359823f3a61e2a34d8997b01b28
Story: #2002586
Task: #24325

commit_message:
Ensures Nginx GPG key is installed

Uses the rpm_key module to ensure the key is installed
so that the nginx package can install correctly.
Helps get around this bug:

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/20711

Change-Id: Id24d041b5ac0f0b29a3ac8aabbe12bf926f9803a

commit_message:
Remove extra information from std.ssh action

The ssh error message can lead to information leak.
Removing the extra ssh message effects only the CLI call,
the full message is still being logged

Change-Id: I0b28e1cb17d4ce3ae711a25b6eaffb4ebf00ccd6
Closes-Bug: 1783708
(cherry picked from commit c93b45a61f49d4633f76d8e117cd89063e7759c4)

commit_message:
Do not dump all instances in the scheduler

There is a log message in the scheduler which dumps all instances
running on a compute host. There are at least 2 problems with this:
1. it generates huge amount of logs which are not really useful
2. it crashes when there is an instance with non-ascii name

Instead of fixing 2), just print instance UUIDs.

Closes-Bug: #1790126
Related-Bug: #1620692
Change-Id: I0eda1c58a7eb54121230c880818b4b1d0fdf4893

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-07 09:53:18.000000000', 'message': 'Use openstack-tox-cover template

Use openstack-tox-cover template, this runs the cover job as
non-voting in the check queue only.

Remove jobs and use template instead.

Change-Id: Ia1c1a4af45d5bc60d94cd1bfc48ccb9385088720
'}, {'created': '2018-09-08 13:37:33.000000000', 'message': 'Update cover jobs

Remove post job, this is not checked by anybody. The current job is
setup as check job and compares to last change, so no need for a post
job - especially for a post job that nobody checks.

Change-Id: Ia1c1a4af45d5bc60d94cd1bfc48ccb9385088720
'}]
commit_message:
Update cover jobs

Remove post job, this is not checked by anybody. The current job is
setup as check job and compares to last change, so no need for a post
job - especially for a post job that nobody checks.

Change-Id: Ia1c1a4af45d5bc60d94cd1bfc48ccb9385088720

commit_message:
Use openstack-tox-cover template

Use openstack-tox-cover template, this runs the cover job
in the check queue only.

Remove jobs and use template instead.

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

subject: Do not verify HTTPS response for self-signed certification
messages:
[{'account_id': 28180, 'date': '2018-09-10 05:09:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-09-10 05:09:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

commit_message:
Cleanup .zuul.yaml

Remove cover job from gate, we run it only in check, see
openstack-cover-jobs template.

Remove required projects for tox-docs job. These are not needed
anymore with current publish-openstack-docs-pti setup and use of
doc/requirements. Remove the individual jobs that are now duplicated.

Change-Id: Iaadb2d65ae0dde716f5691ff08c7f3184b503f8b

subject: Provide the real path of device for ceph to prepare
messages:
[{'account_id': 23650, 'date': '2018-08-31 17:23:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23650, 'date': '2018-08-31 17:29:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 20634, 'date': '2018-09-10 12:36:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I believe that there was some discussion recently about preferring to use the symlinks for ceph related disk configurations as dname links should always be pointed at the correct device, even when the /dev/bcacheN names could change between boots.

If I recall, the dbame link would always point at the correct /dev/bcacheN after reboots'}, {'account_id': 20634, 'date': '2018-09-10 12:39:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

https://github.com/openstack/charm-ceph-osd/commit/488f7dffefa2fdf9bf439d676103c0168f21d2ea is the change I was thinking about,r egarding ensuring that the real device is used'}, {'account_id': 23650, 'date': '2018-09-10 12:45:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Provide the real path of device for ceph to prepare

This is a followup patch for the previous commits that are
addressing issues with bcache based configuration.

Providing dname path for ceph-disk is unsafe, the prepare command
uses gdisk which breaks the dname symlinks.

Change-Id: Id3f360c90d40b77720d7bc7c1bf94b79f71b6827
Closes-Bug: 1790186
Signed-off-by: Gabor Meszaros <gabor.meszaros@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Fix db model inconsistency for FederatedUser

The protocol_id and idp_id in federated user table is cascading
deleted with the federation_protocol table. But the sql model
doesn't. The model lost 'CASCADE' property.

Change-Id: I26f0cd600aa6248da4f190e933129bf2b7de1284

[{'created': '2018-09-09 15:13:14.000000000', 'message': 'Rework the package upgrade after repos

This moves back the generic upgrade process
for packages after the repos are added back
to the run_tests.sh script.

Instead if solves the known python-chardet
dependency bug for requests package for RPM
packaging in the repos.pp manifest.

This is because we need to fix that bug when
running the beaker tests.

We need to keep an eye out if we see any
similar bugs in the future now that updates
are now executed for all packages in beaker
tests.

Change-Id: If12897355d5a4ba7c05e6ee79d63417fcae03977
'}]
commit_message:
Rework the package upgrade after repos

This moves back the generic upgrade process
for packages after the repos are added back
to the run_tests.sh script.

Instead if solves the known python-chardet
dependency bug for requests package for RPM
packaging in the repos.pp manifest.

This is because we need to fix that bug when
running the beaker tests.

We need to keep an eye out if we see any
similar bugs in the future now that updates
are now executed for all packages in beaker
tests.

Change-Id: If12897355d5a4ba7c05e6ee79d63417fcae03977

commit_message:
Fix bug when deleting subnets with revision numbers

We were attempting to delete the revision number for a wrong type
when deleting a subnet. This caused the maintenance task to detect
inconsistencies forever and attempt to fix them with no success.

This patch is fixing the bug and adding converage on functional
tests.

Change-Id: I852a69b81150d2d1afb39bed542ca776548ea114
Closes-Bug: #1790659
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 52d22da487afb1800c53c3d0b43d5efec036fc24)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-21 11:43:56.000000000', 'message': "Support Port Groups in networking-ovn

A new feature has been introduced in core OVN which allows to define
a group of ports and assign ACLs to those. This patch is making use
of the new feature if supported by the underlying OVS version.

As a result we'll be modelling Neutron Security Groups as OVN Port
Groups and we won't be adding one ACL per Security Group Rule per
port. Instead, just add one single ACL per Security Group. This will
also tackle the race conditions that we had for Address Sets as those
will just be used for Remote Security Groups and will be automatically
generated/deleted by core OVN in SB database upon Port Group creation/
deletion.

The major benefit of this patch is that we'll reduce the number of
ACL's dramatically, resulting in a performance leap as discussed at:
https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-discuss/2018-February/046166.html

This patch will address the migration of old Security Groups being
modelled as Address Sets if the OVN schema supports the feature. This
migration will be performed from the OvnWorker which is holding a lock
on the IDL. This ensures that the migration happens from only one worker
in the cloud and after it's done, all the neutron-server instances are
ready to use Port Groups.

Closes-Bug: #1752897
Co-Authored-By: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I35d5ec40c666e92b92b9d664e9615c6fecde595a
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit f01169b405bb5080a1bc1653f79512eb0664c35d)
"}, {'created': '2018-08-21 15:48:02.000000000', 'message': "Support Port Groups in networking-ovn

a group of ports and assign ACLs to those. This patch is making use
of the new feature if supported by the underlying OVS version.

As a result we'll be modelling Neutron Security Groups as OVN Port
Groups and we won't be adding one ACL per Security Group Rule per
port. Instead, just add one single ACL per Security Group. This will
also tackle the race conditions that we had for Address Sets as those
will just be used for Remote Security Groups and will be automatically
generated/deleted by core OVN in SB database upon Port Group creation/
deletion.

The major benefit of this patch is that we'll reduce the number of
ACL's dramatically, resulting in a performance leap as discussed at:
https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-discuss/2018-February/046166.html

This patch will address the migration of old Security Groups being
modelled as Address Sets if the OVN schema supports the feature. This
migration will be performed from the OvnWorker which is holding a lock
on the IDL. This ensures that the migration happens from only one worker
in the cloud and after it's done, all the neutron-server instances are
ready to use Port Groups.

Closes-Bug: #1752897
Co-Authored-By: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I35d5ec40c666e92b92b9d664e9615c6fecde595a
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit f01169b405bb5080a1bc1653f79512eb0664c35d)
"}, {'created': '2018-08-31 12:09:12.000000000', 'message': "Support Port Groups in networking-ovn

A new feature has been introduced in core OVN which allows to define
a group of ports and assign ACLs to those. This patch is making use
of the new feature if supported by the underlying OVS version.

As a result we'll be modelling Neutron Security Groups as OVN Port
Groups and we won't be adding one ACL per Security Group Rule per
port. Instead, just add one single ACL per Security Group. This will
also tackle the race conditions that we had for Address Sets as those
will just be used for Remote Security Groups and will be automatically
generated/deleted by core OVN in SB database upon Port Group creation/
deletion.

The major benefit of this patch is that we'll reduce the number of
ACL's dramatically, resulting in a performance leap as discussed at:
https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-discuss/2018-February/046166.html

This patch will address the migration of old Security Groups being
modelled as Address Sets if the OVN schema supports the feature. This
migration will be performed from the OvnWorker which is holding a lock
on the IDL. This ensures that the migration happens from only one worker
in the cloud and after it's done, all the neutron-server instances are
ready to use Port Groups.

Closes-Bug: #1752897
Co-Authored-By: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I35d5ec40c666e92b92b9d664e9615c6fecde595a
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit f01169b405bb5080a1bc1653f79512eb0664c35d)
"}, {'created': '2018-08-31 12:18:33.000000000', 'message': "Support Port Groups in networking-ovn

A new feature has been introduced in core OVN which allows to define
a group of ports and assign ACLs to those. This patch is making use
of the new feature if supported by the underlying OVS version.

As a result we'll be modelling Neutron Security Groups as OVN Port
Groups and we won't be adding one ACL per Security Group Rule per
port. Instead, just add one single ACL per Security Group. This will
also tackle the race conditions that we had for Address Sets as those
will just be used for Remote Security Groups and will be automatically
generated/deleted by core OVN in SB database upon Port Group creation/
deletion.

The major benefit of this patch is that we'll reduce the number of
ACL's dramatically, resulting in a performance leap as discussed at:
https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-discuss/2018-February/046166.html

This patch will address the migration of old Security Groups being
modelled as Address Sets if the OVN schema supports the feature. This
migration will be performed from the OvnWorker which is holding a lock
on the IDL. This ensures that the migration happens from only one worker
in the cloud and after it's done, all the neutron-server instances are
ready to use Port Groups.

NOTE: This also squashes I706199109a3b7dd5339c90b731f8cb8f04ca4f49

Closes-Bug: #1752897
Closes-Bug: #1790118
Co-Authored-By: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I35d5ec40c666e92b92b9d664e9615c6fecde595a
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit f01169b405bb5080a1bc1653f79512eb0664c35d)
"}, {'created': '2018-08-31 12:29:43.000000000', 'message': "Support Port Groups in networking-ovn

A new feature has been introduced in core OVN which allows to define
a group of ports and assign ACLs to those. This patch is making use
of the new feature if supported by the underlying OVS version.

As a result we'll be modelling Neutron Security Groups as OVN Port
Groups and we won't be adding one ACL per Security Group Rule per
port. Instead, just add one single ACL per Security Group. This will
also tackle the race conditions that we had for Address Sets as those
will just be used for Remote Security Groups and will be automatically
generated/deleted by core OVN in SB database upon Port Group creation/
deletion.

The major benefit of this patch is that we'll reduce the number of
ACL's dramatically, resulting in a performance leap as discussed at:
https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-discuss/2018-February/046166.html

This patch will address the migration of old Security Groups being
modelled as Address Sets if the OVN schema supports the feature. This
migration will be performed from the OvnWorker which is holding a lock
on the IDL. This ensures that the migration happens from only one worker
in the cloud and after it's done, all the neutron-server instances are
ready to use Port Groups.

NOTE: This also squashes I706199109a3b7dd5339c90b731f8cb8f04ca4f49

Closes-Bug: #1752897
Closes-Bug: #1790118
